Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Nanoscale Ultrafast Dynamic Mechanical Analysis (nu-DMA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop technologies to enable commercialization of nanoscale Dynamic Mechanical Analysis (DMA). Conventional DMA works by applying an oscillating stress to a sample and measuring the time-dependent strain. Analysis of DMA data gives information about material stiffness, viscosity, thermal transitions and activation energies, for example. DMA is a critical and widely used tool to measure the viscoelastic properties of bulk materials, but it suffers from three key limitations: slow speed, limited frequency range, and the lack of spatially-resolved information. Large and growing material classes employ nanoscale composite structures to achieve desired material properties. No current tool can rapidly examine the temperature-dependent viscoelastic response of these materials on the scales they are being engineered. To address this unmet need, we will extend successful Phase I research to develop instrumentation based on atomic force microscopy (AFM) using rapidly heatable AFM cantilever probes. Specifically, the nanoscale DMA platform will provide: (1) variable temperature DMA in seconds; (2) measurement frequencies three orders of magnitude higher than conventional DMA; (3) spatial resolution down to < 100 nm; and (4) sensitive and spatially-resolved measurements of glass transitions on wide range of commercially important polymers not previously measurable.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will stretch across multiple industries and academic research areas. Metrology and characterization are foundations of successful materials science and materials manufacturing. The lack of materials characterization tools at the nanoscale has been identified by the chemical industry as a key bottleneck for the rapid development of new materials. This proposal aims to fill a major gap in required instrumentation. With the ability to measure temperature-dependent viscoelastic properties at the nanoscale, materials scientists and engineers will be able for the first time to directly investigate local material stiffness, energy absorption, and damping in heterogeneous materials over a wide range of operating temperatures and frequencies. In addition to spatially resolved measurements, the dramatic measurement speed improvements (a thousand-fold improvement over conventional DMA) will enable higher measurement throughput, lower cost per measurement, more frequent sampling and better measurement statistics. Based on interactions with customers in diverse industries, we have already has already identified strong market pull in areas including epoxies, polymer blends, multilayer films, medical devices, semiconductor packaging, and aerospace markets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The goal of this research was to develop technologies and instrumentation for rapidly measuring the mechanical properties of a broad range of materials over wide frequency and temperature ranges with nanometer-scale spatial resolution.  This project was undertaken to address a two critical gaps in previously available instrumentation:   (1) Bulk measurements of viscoelasticity are slow and tedious and give little or no information about complex heterogeneous materials; and (2) Existing techniques for nanoscale measurement had very limited applicability in terms of the ranges of available temperature, frequency and sample stiffness.  The research in this project focused heavily on the development of a technique called Lorentz Contact Resonance (LCR) that applies an electromagnetic force to the tip of an atomic force microscope (AFM) on a self-heatable cantilever.  The self-heatable cantilever enables rapid controlled heating of a nanoscale region of a sample to temperatures up to several hundred degrees C in fractions of a second, providing extremely rapid measurements of temperature dependent properties of materials.  The LCR technique generates an oscillatory force the AFM tip and a sample surface where the oscillating force could be rapidly swept over a wide frequency range.  The wide frequency range of this technique enables it to probe frequency dependent material properties but also provides a large dynamic range of material stiffness making it applicable an extremely wide range of materials, from soft rubbers to materials as stiff as metals, semiconductors and even graphene.  The resulting instrumentation enabled nanoscale measurements of material viscoelasticity with 1000X higher speed than conventional bulk techniques and spatial resolution down to a few nanometers.  The associated innovations have been recognized by two patents, U.S. Pat. No. 8,914,911 and 8,533,861.

Broader Impacts

The techniques and instrumentation developed during this SBIR project has been used to perform nanoscale materials analysis on an extremely diverse range of samples from a similarly diverse set of research fields in academia and industry.  During this project the team performed nanoscale mechanical analysis on samples for construction materials, polymer blends, laminated multilayer films, semiconductors, biological materials, drug formulations and others.  These are materials that are widely used in a wide range of application areas including healthcare, defense/aerospace, automotive, consumer electronics, pharmaceutical, sporting equipment, as well as food, beverage and drug packaging.  In the In fact, during this project we had researchers in many of these disciplines contact us and request that we perform measurements on critical materials using the techniques developed during this project.  In each of these cases, the researchers we striving to understand the nanoscale structure and composition of their materials. The nanomechanical characterization techniques and instrumentation developed under this project provides a new platform for scientific discovery and the associated insights are already being used to develop higher performance materials.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

This project was undertaken to address a two critical gaps in previously available instrumentation: (1) Bulk measurements of viscoelasticity are slow and tedious and give little or no information about complex heterogeneous materials; and (2) Existing techniques for nanoscale measurement had very limited applicability in terms of the ranges of available temperature, frequency and sample stiffness. The research in this project focused heavily on the development of a technique called Lorentz Contact Resonance (LCR) that applies an electromagnetic force to the tip of an atomic force microscope (AFM) on a self-heatable cantilever. The self-heatable cantilever enables rapid controlled heating of a nanoscale region of a sample to temperatures up to several hundred degrees C in fractions of a second, providing extremely rapid measurements of temperature dependent properties of materials. The LCR technique generates an oscillatory force the AFM tip and a sample surface where the oscillating force could be rapidly swept over a wide frequency range. The wide frequency range of this technique enables it to probe frequency dependent material properties but also provides a large dynamic range of material stiffness making it applicable an extremely wide range of materials, from soft rubbers to materials as stiff as metals, semiconductors and even graphene. The resulting instrumentation enabled nanoscale measurements of material viscoelasticity with 1000X higher speed than conventional bulk techniques and spatial resolution down to a few nanometers. The associated innovations have been recognized by two patents, U.S. Pat. No. 8,914,911 and 8,533,861. Broader Impacts The techniques and instrumentation developed during this SBIR project has been used to perform nanoscale materials analysis on an extremely diverse range of samples from a similarly diverse set of research fields in academia and industry. During this project the team performed nanoscale mechanical analysis on samples for construction materials, polymer blends, laminated multilayer films, semiconductors, biological materials, drug formulations and others. These are materials that are widely used in a wide range of application areas including healthcare, defense/aerospace, automotive, consumer electronics, pharmaceutical, sporting equipment, as well as food, beverage and drug packaging. In the In fact, during this project we had researchers in many of these disciplines contact us and request that we perform measurements on critical materials using the techniques developed during this project. In each of these cases, the researchers we striving to understand the nanoscale structure and composition of their materials. The nanomechanical characterization techniques and instrumentation developed under this project provides a new platform for scientific discovery and the associated insights are already being used to develop higher performance materials.
